newsitem.title: UK: NWE naphtha steady as exports East support.
newsitem.headline: NWE naphtha steady as exports East support.

text.p: NWE naphtha was steady on Tuesday as perceptions of tight supply later this week held prices up, despite softer crude prices.
Traders noted, however, that the market was extremely quiet in the wake of the Easter holidays.
On swaps, April paper was quoted around $193.50/$194.50 in early trade, but was assessed back up around $197.50/$198 later.
Players said the contango was still in place with May paper judged to be $1.0 above April's.
"You'd expect naphtha to have fallen in line with the crude," said one broker.
"But with so much material having gone East I think a couple of players might be considering putting a squeeze on the market."
Players have estimated that anything from 300,000 to 700,000 tonnes of naphtha have left Europe for the East over the past month.
"We're not seeing it full effects on the Eastern market just yet because it's a thirty day journey and none of the cargoes have got there yet," said the broker.
He noted that prices in Japan and Singapore had already weakened slightly on Tuesday.
Meanwhile in Europe, one player was heard to be bidding for pipeline material at about $195 cif NWE, while full range material was pegged around $185/$192 cif NWE.
Naphtha barge were assessed around quotes fob cif hi =50 cents.
